citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A six-year-old female Shiba Inu dog, identified #9221, is observed with right-hind limb lameness and two lacerations, five
and six inches from the tail base, respectively. The dog is observed eating normally and navigating throughout its
enclosure, but only intermittently places weight on the affected limb. The laceration closest to the tail base spans the
width of the tail, measuring 1-inch wide and 0.5-inch long, and exposes deeper underlying tissue with adjacent dark skin;
there is minimal discharge present. The other laceration, measuring 0.5-inch wide and 1-inch long, is a more superficial
laceration that is similarly surrounded by dark skin but has no discharge present. A facility representative stated the
lameness had been identified on Saturday, March 1, 2025, at which point the dog was immediately moved to separate
housing for monitoring. The facility's written Program of Veterinary Care, however, does not provide guidance for
monitoring or managing lameness nor wound care, nor was the veterinarian contacted for guidance.
As lameness of this nature is a sign of pain, and as open wounds may require thorough assessment and care, failure to
seek care or establishing guidance for addressing these issues may result in unnecessarily prolonged pain or other
medical risks. The facility must assure these injuries are addressed by a veterinarian and, going forward, must continue to
maintain appropriate methods for diagnosing and treating medical problems. At the time of inspection, the facility
representative notified the Attending Veterinarian and confirmed with the inspector that a plan for care of these injuries
was arranged.
Correct by end of day, March 5, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A six-year-old female Shiba Inu dog, identified #9221, is observed with right-hind limb lameness and two lacerations, five 
and six inches from the tail base, respectively. The dog is observed eating normally and navigating throughout its 
enclosure, but only intermittently places weight on the affected limb. The laceration closest to the tail base spans the 
width of the tail, measuring 1-inch wide and 0.5-inch long, and exposes deeper underlying tissue with adjacent dark skin; 
there is minimal discharge present. The other laceration, measuring 0.5-inch wide and 1-inch long, is a more superficial 
laceration that is similarly surrounded by dark skin but has no discharge present. A facility representative stated the 
lameness had been identified on Saturday, March 1, 2025, at which point the dog was immediately moved to separate 
housing for monitoring. The facility's written Program of Veterinary Care, however, does not provide guidance for 
monitoring or managing lameness nor wound care, nor was the veterinarian contacted for guidance.  
As lameness of this nature is a sign of pain, and as open wounds may require thorough assessment and care, failure to 
seek care or establishing guidance for addressing these issues may result in unnecessarily prolonged pain or other 
medical risks. The facility must assure these injuries are addressed by a veterinarian and, going forward, must continue to 
maintain appropriate methods for diagnosing and treating medical problems. At the time of inspection, the facility 
representative notified the Attending Veterinarian and confirmed with the inspector that a plan for care of these injuries 
was arranged.  
 
Correct by end of day, March 5, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
